column5: and the nuclear family arguably reducing in prominence.

column1: === Feminism ===

The proportion of young girls considering themselves feminists has risen from 35% in 2013 to 47% in 2018.  36% of young women and girls aged 11 to 21 had spoken up about an issue that mattered to them

column1: == Naming conventions ==
The common naming convention throughout the United Kingdom is for everyone to have one or more given names (a forename
column2: still often referred to as a "Christian name") usually (but not always) indicating the child's sex
column3: and a surname ("family name"). A four-year study by the University of the West of England
column4: which concluded in 2016
column5: analysed sources dating from the 11th to the 19th centuries to explain the origins of the surnames in the British Isles. The study found that over 90% of the 45
column6: 602 surnames in the dictionary are native to the British Isles; the most common in the UK are Smith
column7: Jones
column8: Williams
column9: Brown
column10: Taylor
column11: Johnson
column12: and Lee. Since the 19th century middle names (additional forenames) have become very common and are sometimes taken from the name of a family member.
